greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array read by falling antidiagonals, where A(n,k) = floor(A337472(n, k)/A337470(n, k)); Abundancy index of A337470(n, k) floored down.
comment: Array is read by descending antidiagonals with n >= 0 and k >= 1 ranging as: (0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 1), (0, 3), (1, 2), (2, 1), (0, 4), (1, 3), (2, 2), (3, 1), ...
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10584; the first 145 antidiagonals of array
Index entries for sequences computed from indices in prime factorization
Index entries for sequences related to primorial numbers
Index entries for sequences related to sigma(n)
example: The top left corner of the array begins as:
A337474 gives the distance in each column to the first 1 in that column, being 0 for columns 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ..., where 1 is already in the top row.
program: A337473sq(n, k) = if(1==k,k, my(f=factor(k), h = #f~, prevpid=primepi(f[h,1]), e=f[h,2], p, s=1); forstep(i=h-1,0,-1, if(!i,pid=0,pid=primepi(f[i,1])); forstep(j=prevpid,(1+pid),-1, p=prime(j+n); s *= ((p^(1+e)-1)/((p-1)*(p^e)))); if(!pid,return(floor(s))); prevpid = pid; e += f[i,2]); floor(s));
A337473list(up_to) = { my(v = vector(1+up_to), i=0); for(a=0, oo, for(b=1, a, i++; if(i > #v, return(v)); v[i] = A337473sq(b-1, (a-(b-1))))); (v); };
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Aug 28 2020
